channel.title: Does your success come from school?
channel.description:
School is a source of education. But, not everyone pursues the rest of their life based on what they learn in their classes. To some people, the classes they've taken in school were just as valuable as lunch.
Do you believe your grade in school defines how intelligent you are? Does it truly affect your future and opportunity toward success, or is it only a stepping stone in the right path?
Discuss.

item.title: Does your success come from school?
item.dc:creator: @jc22493 Jc22493
item.description:
@jc22493 wrote:

B2300 T4nk:

College was made so you can learn more about your favorite thing.

No, college was established for religious purposes.

Read full topic

item.title: Does your success come from school?
item.dc:creator: @jc22493 Jc22493
item.description:
@jc22493 wrote:

[quote=“LilXCj, post:39, topic:330829”]My grades are terrible.

My SAT and State Testing scores are excellent though.

What really shows your intelligence is how you apply it to those around you. School is just a record that colleges look at so they don’t have to interview you one by one.

Make average grades in advanced classes and do well in sports. You’ll get into a decent college which can only ‘jump start’ your life.

You don’t need college to have a good life.

It’s just recommended[/quote]
In this society, you do. (Majority.)

Read full topic

item.description:
@Mod_Adam wrote:

[quote=“casey., post:31, topic:330829”]He’s a genius in his field of comedy. Obviously genius can cover an array of things.

If your not smart you have a chance to make it in sports.

iirc, it’s about a 10% chance of going pro in any sport.
Athletics are so competitive, and professional teams, hell even colleges only want the best of the best of players. If you even use this site, chances are you will not go anywhere in athletics.[/quote]
I got offered positions on 2 college hockey teams. d3, but hey… Also got asked to tryout for a junior team in New York. I already accepted to Eckerd College though.

item.title: Does your success come from school?
item.dc:creator: @doom_j doom_j
item.description:
@doom_j wrote:

I feel grades shouldn’t define how smart a person is, because yeah they might of gotten a 100% in the class, that doesn’t mean they know what there talking about. I have a very low score in English 11 yet on my mid year I got a 90% on it. On the other hand my sister she had a good grade in the class like a 80-90, she got a 60-70% on her mid year. Also when we had our in class interviews for a job we picked in the 7th grade I got a 90% she got a 70% and I failed half the year in that. So no your success doesn’t always come from school.

Read full topic

item.title: Does your success come from school?
item.dc:creator: @Lin Lin
item.description:
@Lin wrote:

[quote=“Jc22493, post:34, topic:330829”]Grades in school don’t represent anything, but the majority cannot succeed without decent grades, a fail aspect of our society.[/quote]I second this. Grades really do NOT depend on how smart you are. A lot of it comes from creativity and the amount of effort you put into things. Some are the reason they are for non-academic reasons. For example, my English teacher had us bring in a notebook and it was an assignment worth 45 points. I didn’t and you can imagine what it did to my grade.

Read full topic
item.source: Does your success come from school?

item.title: Does your success come from school?
item.dc:creator: @jc22493 Jc22493
item.description:
@jc22493 wrote:

Grades in school don’t represent anything, but the majority cannot succeed without decent grades, a fail aspect of our society.

But… School isn’t only a source of education. In fact, it can probably be seen more as a valuable experience; gaining friends, seeing how the ‘real’ world works, even though we see little of it, etc.

Read full topic
item.source: Does your success come from school?

item.title: Does your success come from school?
item.dc:creator: @JaydenD12 JaydenD12
item.description:
@JaydenD12 wrote:

[quote=“Primadude, post:3, topic:330829”][quote author=The Reaper X link=topic=427202.msg3137250#msg3137250 date=1267134616]
School is a source of education. But, not everyone pursues the rest of their life based on what they learn in their classes. To some people, the classes they’ve taken in school were just as valuable as lunch.

Do you believe your grade in school defines how intelligent you are? Does it truly affect your future and opportunity toward success, or is it only a stepping stone in the right path?

Discuss.
[/quote]

Up to a certain point in your school life, your classes may not be of any worth to you, however, when you turn 14/15 you can choose the subjects you want to take, which is part of pursuing what path you want to follow in life. On top of this, in the UK most jobs nowadays require 5+ GCSEs A*-C (Which must include English & Mathematics), so this part of life is compulsory if you’re wanting to get a half decent job if you don’t wish to pursue any further education beyond this point.

For example, when I was 14/15 I chose the following four GCSEs:

  • Triple Science (Biology, Chemistry, Physics).
  • Business Studies.
  • I.C.T.
  • Geography.

On top of those I had to continue with the compulsory classes such as Mathematics, Physical Education (P.E), Religious Education etc. The only GCSE choice I regretted taking is Geography; the teacher I had hated me and the feeling was mutual, therefore making that class hell for me. After the two year course I passed all four of the above subjects as well as the compulsory subjects (Excluding Religious Education; I failed that miserably :P).

To be honest, you don’t really need any qualifications if you’re not going to be working for anyone else (i.e. creating your own business/company), but it’s highly unlikely that you would get very far without basic qualifications such as the ones stated above (5 GCSEs A*-C). I mean if you were to create the next best invention or food product, then you’d be rich for life and wouldn’t need to pursue any further education (unless you felt the need to).

Though, some people may not think that success is all about their wealth and education; some people believe that success is having a happy family or something along those lines.[/quote]

I chose Geography, IMT and History.

Read full topic
item.source: Does your success come from school?

item.title: Does your success come from school?
item.dc:creator: @The_Reaper_X The Reaper X
item.description:
@The_Reaper_X wrote:

[quote=“Old Rsc Player, post:30, topic:330829”][quote author=casey. link=topic=427202.msg3137915#msg3137915 date=1267222344]
@The Repear X
Those people are also geniuses.

None of you are as smart as Gates and will never amount to a high paying job.
[/quote]

If your not smart you have a chance to make it in sports.

Also the guy who owns the company with the most expensive stock applied for harvard and was denied. College doesnt mean shit.[/quote]Truth is, there is no real way to force proof of intelligence. Grades are voluntary proof of the work you want to show to colleges. They are their for proof that you understand enough to reach a certain requirement. College is voluntary, as they look at what you’ve shown for your intelligence via GPA, SAT, ACT, and so on. If you don’t feel like taking the opportunity to establish a good foundation to show, that’s your choice.

[quote=“casey., post:31, topic:330829”]He’s a genius in his field of comedy. Obviously genius can cover an array of things.[/quote]Oh, I didn’t know you were insinuating that. I just saw the link you made to Bill Gates and being a genius. There is nothing preventing someone with determination from becoming equally skilled, if not better, in a roll in society. Of course there are handicaps that make things more difficult, and positions that are more demanding than others, but it doesn’t mean you’re eliminated from a future of success. There are so many ways to become successful, that it’s almost ignorant to assume the only reason they are successful is because they’re geniuses.

Read full topic

item.source: Does your success come from school?

item.title: Does your success come from school?
item.dc:creator: @CoonHunter CoonHunter
item.description:
@CoonHunter wrote:

[quote=“casey., post:27, topic:330829”]@The Repear X
Those people are also geniuses.

None of you are as smart as Gates and will never amount to a high paying job.[/quote]

Just so everybody is clear, Bill Gates was not the only original founder of Microsoft. We give him more credit than he actually deserves.

“a group at the Xerox Palo Alto Research Center (PARC) developed the Alto, a GUI-based computer”
This meaning - The main chunk of Microsoft and apple as we know it, they did not even invent, they simply re-created.
Source: http://planethomo.typepad.com/planethomo/2007/02/which_came_firs.html

“they bought DOS from some guy who wrote it in his garage, made a few small changes, and sold it to IBM”
This meaning - The original Microsoft, was never invented by Gates at all, but simply was bought because he had the money.
Source: http://uk.answers.yahoo.com/question/index?qid=20090521041033AAivwV1

“Microsoft was started in 1975 and Apple in 1976. They worked together on a BASIC programming language called AppleSoft BASIC - the name being a combination of Apple and Microsoft for the Apple computer”
Source: http://wiki.answers.com/Q/What_came_out_first_Apple_or_Microsoft

Bill Gates isn’t such a genius after all now is he? Yes, he is smart, but we do give him more credit than what he has earned. The basis to what we know as Windows was not even his to begin with, yet we say it as though.

Sorry for going off-topic, just clearing some up about this. It drives me crazy when people use him as an example when someone else could have been chosen who deserves it.

Read full topic

item.title: Does your success come from school?
item.dc:creator: @The_Reaper_X The Reaper X
item.description:
@The_Reaper_X wrote:

[quote=“krackkid, post:25, topic:330829”]School doesn’t make the person…The way you act/think is what will give you your success.[/quote]I view it the same as you, but with a format, a layout if you will. Within the journey to success, there are milestones that require capability or expectations. There are a number of ways to perceiving these expectations, and in the end it doesn’t matter what you use to accomplish them but rather how you accomplish them. The amount of input within the path to success will no doubt determine the amount of success you receive. The concentration that your “following” supports is essential as to what your capable of accomplishing. It’s all about making the right decisions, pushing the right buttons, and swaying your peers into boosting your chances, because it’s nearly impossible to fully accomplish anything alone.

Read full topic

item.title: Does your success come from school?
item.dc:creator: @The_Reaper_X The Reaper X
item.description:
@The_Reaper_X wrote:

[quote=“casey., post:7, topic:330829”]Of course it does.
If your smart but don’t apply yourself and get a bad GPA, than your not getting into a good college.
If your smart and apply yourself, congratulations, you’re going to a great college.
In America if you want a good future, a college degree is what you need.[/quote]

“Bill Gates started studying at Harvard University in 1973 where he spent time with Paul Allen. Gates and Allen worked on a version of the programming language BASIC, that was the basis for the MITS Altair (the first microcomputer available). He did not go on to graduate from Harvard University as he left in his junior year to start what was to become the largest computer software company in the world; Microsoft Corporation.”

Bill Gates finished with a Sans degree, hardly what he was capable of. Though, you could still support the fact that it expresses exponential proof in “college requirement”. I’d suggest you look at this:

http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_college_dropout_billionaires

[hr]

And although he’s not successful, working as a bouncer, the smartest man in the world with an estimated IQ of 190-210 straight up left college. (He tells the story in video 2)


One Man's Blog – 6 Nov 07

Smartest Man in the World Espouses Virtues of Eugenics

Chris Langan is the World’s Smartest Man. That’s not an opinion, it’s a statement of fact. Mr. Langan’s IQ is nearly 200. Oh, and he’s spent 20 years being a bouncer at a bar. This guy has had a rough life. As a kid he was abused by other kids and...

[hr]

[quote=" story of George Eastman"]
Creator of the Kodak Camera Company, George Eastman, was forced to drop out of school due to financial circumstances. At only 14, his father died and the only way George could keep his two sisters and mother alive was to quit school and begin working as an office boy full time. By the age of 26, Eastman found his true calling and began working to improve the emulsion process involved in photography. He thought the liquid emulsions proved quite a problem as they were excessively sticky and had to be used quickly before they dried. In only three years, Eastman had perfected his dry emulsion plates and he started his own photographic business in 1880.[/quote]

[hr]

And if there isn’t promise in such things listed above, following a path in the arts is a potentially great way to becoming successful. Take Richard Prior for example:

[quote=" Richard Prior Story"]
He was raised in his grandmother’s brothel, where his mother “worked” and his father served as her pimp. At only ten, his mother abandoned him and his strict grandmother took over his care, beating him whenever she thought he was acting “eccentric.” With a home life like this, it’s not all to surprising that he ended up being expelled from high school at 14.

In the end, Pryor ended up proving the adage that “whatever doesn’t kill you only makes you stronger” and his comedy career was one of the longest lasting and most successful of the last fifty years.[/quote]

Richard Prior has been introduced as the best comedian numerous amounts of times;

[ul][li]Comedy Central[/li]
[li]http://www.dead-frog.com/comedians/best_overall/[/li]
[li]List After List[/li]
[li]http://digitaldreamdoor.nutsie.com/pages/quotes/greatest-stand-up-comedians.html
[/li][/ul]

[hr]

Richard Prior and George Eastman are both listed in 7 Highly Successful Highschool Dropouts

There’s also a larger list of persona that come from various different backgrounds, listing a multitude of career positions:

http://www.school-survival.net/successful_dropouts.php

If this isn’t enough to curve your insistence on a degree, I don’t know how else to entice your opinion. Though, everyone has their own, I’m only here to strike up a decent discussion, as I’m tired of talking about the same trivial matters on moparscape.

[quote=“casey., post:21, topic:330829”][quote author=CoonHunter link=topic=427202.msg3137498#msg3137498 date=1267156933]
Eeh, i would definatelly say my does not come from school, or parents. My parents are both 9th grade drop-outs. As for school, i go to an alternative school. Not the funnest thing, but i dont do good with 30-40+ people in a classroom, thats why the college im looking at is 28 classroom.
[/quote]
Times have changed since when your parents were kids.
A college degree wasn’t as important in our parents teenage years as it is now.[/quote]Time’s have changed, and that could be your counter-argument to what I’ve posted, but that doesn’t stand in front of the success rate of radical dropouts. One could say there’s no honest way to determine your chance at success after denying the opportunity at a diploma, but for the sake of discussion there’s nearly an infinite opening to potential success without one.

Read full topic

item.title: Does your success come from school?
item.dc:creator: @WowILikeToCode WowILikeToCode
item.description:
@WowILikeToCode wrote:

Well, I’m 15 and made my options last year, (year 9) im now in year 10…

i took

[ul][li]ICT Diploma[/li]
[li]Btec PE[/li][/ul]

Because i did the diploma i could only choose one other option so i chose the one that all my friends took.

It turns out, The IT Diploma Unit 1 is all written by hand and i hated it so i dropped out and now i stay home all day on tuesday’s and wednesdays. and the P.E Btec is a load of shit and thats boring but i’m not aloud to drop out of that…

so i skive on thursdays… and only really go into school on monday and friday morning due to having a reduced timetable because of my behaiviour…

so i don’t really do much learning at school and i just mess about with my mates, but my predicted grade for Math English and science are all B’s.

When i leave school i want to go in the army like my brother,

My brother got

[ul][li]D in english[/li]
[li]D in mathematics[/li]
[li]E in science[/li]
[li]C in art[/li][/ul]

He has been in the army almost 2 years now and he’s earning little below 2 thousand pounds a month.

To conclude,
From my experiences, Our success doesn’t come from school, but from your amvition and doing something about it!

Thanks for reading,
WowILikeToCode,
Thomas

Read full topic

Times have changed since when your parents were kids.
A college degree wasn’t as important in our parents teenage years as it is now.
